langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div.p:
Ford, John: The ladies trial (1639)
Fide Honour.
To my Deservingly-honoured, IOHN WYRLEY Esquire, and to the virtuous and right worthy Gentlewoman, Mrs MARY WYRLEY his wife, This service.

lg.l: Language and matter, with a fit of mirth,
That sharply savours more of air than earth,
Like Midwives, bring a Play to timely birth.
But where is now such a one? in which these three,
Are handsomely contrived? or if they be,
Are understood by all who hear to see.
Wit, wit is the word in fashion, that alone
Cries up the Poet, which though neatly shown,
Is rather censured often-times than known.
He who will venture on a jest, that can
Rail on another's pain, or idly scan
Affairs of state, O he is the only man.
A goodly approbation, which must bring
Fame with contempt, by such a deadly sting,
The Muses chatter, who were wont to sing.
Your favours in what we present today,
Our fearless Author boldly bids me say,
He tenders you no Satyr, but a play.
In which, if so he have not hit all right,
For wit, words, mirth, and matter as he might,
He wishes yet he had for your delight.

div.head: ACTUS PRIMUS.
div.stage: Enter Piero and Futelli at severall doores.

sp.speaker: Piero.
sp.l: Accomplished man of fashion.

sp.speaker: Fvt.
sp.l: The times wonder.
Gallant of gallants Genoas Piero.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Italics darling, Europes joy, and so forth,
The newest news, un-vamped,

sp.speaker: Fvt.
sp.l: I am no foot-post,
No peddler of Aviso's, no monopolist
Of forged Corantos, monger of Gazettes.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Monger of courtesans, fine Futelli,
In certain kind a merchant of the staple
For wares of use and trade, a taker up,
Rather indeed a knocker down, the word
Will carry either sense but in pure earnest,
How trolls the common noise?

sp.speaker: Fvt.
sp.p:
Auria who lately
Wedded and bedded to the fair Spinella,
Tired with the enjoyments of delights, is hasting to cuff the Turkish
pirates, in the service of the great Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Does not carry
His pretty thing along.

sp.speaker: Fvt.
sp.l: Leaves her to buffet
Land pirates here at home.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: That is thou and I,
Futelli (sirra) and Piero -- blockhead
To run from such an arm full of pleasures
For gaining, what? a bloody nose of honour,
Most sottish and abominable.

sp.speaker: Fvt.
sp.p:
wicked
Shameful and cowardly I will maintain.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Is all my seigniors hospitality
Huge banquetings, deep revels, costly trappings
Shrunk to a cabin, and a single welcome
To beverage and biscuit.

sp.speaker: Fvt.
sp.p:
Hold thy peace man.
It makes for us -- he comes, let us part demurely.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: We wish thee (honoured Auria) life and safety,
Return crowned with a victory, whose wreath,
O triumph may advance thy countries glory,
Worthy your name and Ancestors.

sp.speaker: Avr.
sp.l: My Lord,
I shall not live to thrive in any action,
Deserving memory when I forget
Adurnis love and favour.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I present ye
My service for a farewell.

sp.speaker: Fvt.
sp.l: Let few words
Excuse all arts of complement.
For my own part,
Kill or be killed, for there is the short and long of it.
Call me your shadows hinch-boy.

sp.speaker: Avr.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
My business urging on a present haste,
Enforceth short reply.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: We dare not hinder
Your resolution winged with thoughts so constant.
All happiness.

sp.speaker: Pie., Phvt.
sp.l: Contents.

sp.speaker: Avr.
sp.l: So leave the wintered people of the North,
The minutes of their summer, when the Sun
Departing leaves them in Cold robes of Ice,
As I leave Genoa, -- now appears the object
Of my apprenticed heart, thou bringest Spinella
A welcome in a farewell, souls and bodies
Are severed for a time, a span of time;
To join again without all separation,
In a confirmed unity for ever.
Such will our next embraces be for life;
And then to take the wrack of our divisions,
Will sweeten the remembrance of past dangers,
Will fasten love in perpetuity,
Will force our sleeps to steal upon our stories.
These days must come, and shall without a cloud
Or right of fear, or envy: to your charge,
(Trelcatio our good uncle) and the comfort
Of my Spinella's sister, fair Castanna,
I do entrust this treasure.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: I dare promise,
My husbanding that trust with truth and care.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My sister shall to me stand an example,
Of pouring free devotions for your safety.

sp.speaker: Avri.
sp.l: Gentle Castanna, thou art a branch of goodness,
Grown on the self same stock with my Spinella.
But why my dear, hast thou locked up thy speech in so much silent
sadness, O at parting!
Belike one private whisper must be sighed,
Uncle the best of peace enrich your family,
I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: Blessings and health preserve ye.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nay nay Castanna, you may hear our counsels
A while, you are designed your sisters husband,
Give me thy hand Spinella, you did promise,
To send me from you with more cheerful looks,
Without a grudge or tear, deed love you did.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: What friend have I left in your absence?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Many thy vertues are, such friends, they cannot fail thee,
Faith, purity of thoughts and such a meekness,
As would force scandal to a blush.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Admit Sir,
The patent of your life should be called in,
How am I left then to account with griefs;
More slaved to pity than a broken heart?
Auria! soul of my comforts, I let fall
No eye on breach of fortune, I contemn
No entertainment to divided hopes;
I urge no pressures by the scorn of change;
And yet my Auria, when I but conceive
How easy it is (without impossibility)
Never to see thee more, forgive me then,
If I conclude I may be miserable,
Most miserable.
And such conclusion sister
Argues effects of a distrust more voluntary
than cause by likely hood.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: It is truth Castanna.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: I grant it truth, yet Auria I am a woman,
And therefore apt to fear, to show my duty
And not take heart from you, I will walk from ye,
At your command, and not as much as trouble
Your thought with one poor looking back.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I thank thee,
My worthy wife! before we kiss, receive.
This caution from thine Auria, first Castanna
Let us bid farewell.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Speak (good) speak.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: the steps
Young Ladies tread left to their own discretion,
How ever wisely printed are observed
And construed as the lookers on presume,
Point out thy ways then in such even paths,
As thine own jealousies from others tongues
May not intrude a guilt, though undeserved.
Admit of visits as of Physic forced
Not to procure health, but for safe prevention
Against a growing sickness in thy use
Of time and of discourse be found so thrifty,
As no remembrance may impeach thy rest,
Appear not in a fashion that can prompt
The gazers eye, or holla to report;
Some widowed neglect of hand, some value
In recreations be both wise, and free,
Live still at home, home to thyself how-ere
Enriched with noble company, remember
A woman's virtue in her lifetime, writes
The Epitaph all covet on their tombs,
In short I know thou never wilt forget
Whose wife thou art, nor how upon thy lips,
Thy husband at his parting stalled this kiss.
No more.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Dear heaven! go sister, go.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Done bravely,
And like the choice of glory to know mine,
One of earths best I have forgone, -- see, see,
Yet in another I am rich; a friend,
A perfect one, Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Had I been,
No stranger to your bosom Sir, ere now
You might have sorted me in your resolves,
Companion of your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: So the wrongs
I should have ventured on against thy fate
Must have denied all pardon, not to hold
Dispute with reputations, why before
This present instant I concealed the stealth
Of my adventures from the Counsels, know
My wants do drive me hence.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Wants, so you said,
And it was not friendly spoken,

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Hear me further.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Auria take heed, the covert of a folly
Willing to range; be not without excuse
Discovered in the coinage of untruths.
I use no harder language, thou art near
Already on a ship-wrack in forsaking
The holy land of friendship in forsaking
To talk your wants. Fie.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: By that sacred thing
Last issued from the Temple where it dwelt,
I mean our friendship, I am sunk so low
In my estate, that bids me live in Genoa
But six months longer, I survive the remnant
Of all my store.

sp.speaker: Aurel
sp.l: Umh.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: In my Country, friend
Where I have sided my superior friend
Swayed opposition, friend, friend here to fall
Subject to scorn, or rarely found compassion,
Were more than man that hath a soul could bear,
A soul not stooped to servitude.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Your show,
Nor certainty, nor weak assurance yet
Of reparation in this course: in case
Command be proffered.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: He who cannot merit
Preferment by employments, let him bare
His throat unto the Turkish cruelty,
Or die or live a slave without redemption.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: For that so, but you have a wife, a young,
A fair wife; she, though she could never claim
Right in prosperity, was never tempted
By trial of extremes, to youth and beauty,
Baits for dishonour, and a perished fame.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Show me the man that lives, and to my face
Dares speak, scarce think, such tyranny against
Spinellas constancy, except Aurelio
He is my friend.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: There lives not then a friend
Dares love you like Aurelio, that Aurelio,
Who late and early; often said and truly,
Your marriage with Spinella would entangle
As much the opinion due to your discretion,
As your estate, it hath done so to both.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: I find it hath.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: He who prescribes no law,
No limits of condition to the objects
Of his affection; but will merely wed
A face because it is round, or limbed by nature
In purest red and white, or at the best,
For that his mistress owes an excellence
Of qualities, knows when and how to speak,
Where to keep silence, with fit reasons why,
Whose vertues are her only dower, else
In either kind, ought of himself to master
Such fortunes as add fuel to their loves
For otherwise: -- but herein I am idle,
Have fooled to little purpose.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: She is my wife.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: And being so, it is not manly done
To leave her to the trial of her wits,
Her modesty, her innocence, her vows.
This is the way that points her out an art
Of wanton life.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Sir, said ye?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You form reasons,
Just ones, for your abandoning the storms
Which threaten your own ruin; but propose
No shelter for her honour; what my tongue
Hath uttered, Auria, is but honest doubt,
And you are wise enough in the construction.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Necessity must arm my confidence,
Which if I live to triumph over friend,
And ere come back in plenty, I pronounce
Aurelio heir of what I can bequeath.
Some fit deduction for a worthy widow,
Allowed with caution, she be like to prove so.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Who? I your heir? your wife being yet so young,
In every probability so forward
To make you a father? leave such thoughts.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Believe it,
Without replies Aurelio: keep this note,
A warrant for receiving from Martino
Two hundred Ducats; as you find occasion
Dispose them in my absence to Spinella.
I would not trust her uncle, he good man,
Is at an ebb himself, another hundred
I left with her, a fourth I carry with me,
Am I not poor, Aurelio, now? exchange
Of more debates between us, would undo
My resolution: Walk a little prithee,
Friends we are, and will embrace: but let us not speak
Another word.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: I will follow you to your horse.

div.stage: Exit. Enter Adurni and Futelli. A letter.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: With her own hand.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: She never used my Lord,
A second means, but kissed the letter first,
Overlooked the superscription: then let fall
Some amorous drops, kissed it again, talked to it
Twenty times over, set it to her mouth,
Then gave it me, then snatched it back again,
Then cried, O my poor heart, and in an instant
Commend my truth and secrecy, such medley
Of passion yet, I never saw in woman.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: In woman? thou art deceived; but that we both
Had mothers, I could say how women are,
In their own natures, models of mere change:
Of change of what is naught, to what is worse,
She fed ye liberally.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Twenty ducats
She forced on me, vowed by the precious love
She bore the best of men, (I use my lord)
Her very words the miracle of men,
Malfato, (then she sighed) this mite of gold
Was only entrance to a farther bounty,
It is meant (my lord) be like press money.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Devil! how durst she tempt thee, Futelli, knowing
Thy love to me?

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: There lies (my lord) her cunning,
Rather her craft: first she began what pity
It was, that men should differ in estates,
Without proportion some so strangely rich,
Others so miserable poor; and yet,
Quoth she, since it is very deed unfit
All should be equals; so I must confess
It were good justice that the properest men
Should be preferred to fortune, such as nature
Had marked with fair abilities of which
Genoa, for ought I know, hath wondrous few
Not two to boast of.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Here began her itch.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: I answered, she was happy then, whose choice
In you, my lord, was singular.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Well urged.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: She smiled, and said, it might be so, and yet
There stopped: then I closed with her, and concluded
The title of a lord was not enough,
For absolute perfection, I had seen
Persons of meaner quality, much more
Exact in fair endowments; but your Lordship
Will pardon me, I hope.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: And love thee for it.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Phew: let that pass (quoth she) and now we prattle
Of handsome gentlemen, in my opinion,
Malfato is a very pretty fellow,
Is he not, pray Sir, I had then the truth
Of what I roved at: and with more than praise,
Approved her judgment in so high a strain,
Without comparison (my honoured Lord)
That soon we both concluded of the man,
The match and business.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: For delivering
A letter to Malfato.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Whereto I
No sooner had consented, with protests,
(I did protest my Lord) of secrecy,
And service, but she kissed me (as I live)
Of her own free accord -- (I trust your lordship
Conceives not me amiss) pray rip the seal
(My lord) you will find sweet stuff, I dare believe,

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Present to the most accomplished
Of men, Malfato with this
Love a service.
Kind Superscription, prithee find him out,
Deliver it with complement, observe
How ceremoniously he does receive it.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: will not your lordship peruse the contents?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: enough I know too much be just, and cunning
A wanton Mistress is a common sewer
Much never project labours in my brain --
Your friend here is now the Gemini of wit
What odd conceit is next on foot, some cast
Of neat invention, ha sirs.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Very fine,
I do protest my lord.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Your lordships ear shall share in the plot.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: You know my lord
Young Amoretta, old Trelcatio's daughter
An honest man, but poor.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: And my good lord,
He that is honest, must be poor, my lord,
It is a common rule.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Well Amoretta,
Pray one at once my knowledge is not much,
Of her instruct me.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Speak Futelli.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Spare me.
Piero has the tongue more pregnant.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Fie play on your creature.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Nay good.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Well keep your mirth, my dainty honeys agree
Some two days hence, till when --

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: By any means,
Partake the sport, my lord, this thing of youth.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Handsome enough, good face, quick eye, well bred.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Is yet possessed so strangely.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: With an humour of thinking, she deserves --

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: A Duke, a Count.
At least a Viscount, for her husband that --

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: She scorns all mention of a match beneath
One of the foresaid nobles; will not ride
In a caroche without eight horses.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Six, she may be drawn to four --

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Are for the power,
But for two horses in a coach --

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: She says,
They are not for creatures of heavens making fitter --

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Fitter for litters to convey hounds in,
Than people christian yet herself --

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Herself walks evermore a foot, and knows not whether
A Coach doth trot or amble.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: But by hear-say.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Stop gentlemen, you run a gallop both:
Are out of breath sure, it is a kind of complement
Scarce entered to the times, but certainly
You coin a humour, let me understand
Deliberately your fancy.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: In plain troth,
My Lord, the she whom we Describe is such,
And lives here, here in Genoa, this City,
This very city, now, the very now.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Trelcatios daughter.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Has refused suitors
Of worthy rank, substantial and free parts.
Only for that they are not Dukes, or Counts,
Yet she herself with all her fathers store,
Can hardly weigh above four hundred Ducats.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Now your design for sport.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Without prevention,
Guzman the Spaniard late cashiered, most gravely
Observes the full punctilious of his nation,
And him have we beleaguered to accost
This she-piece, under a pretence of being
Grandee of Spain, and cousin to twelve Princes.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: For rival unto whom we have enraged
Fulgoso, the rich coxcomb lately started
A gentleman out of a Sutler's hut,
In the late Flemish wars, we have resolved him
He is Descended from Pantagruel,
Of famous memory by the fathers side,
And by the mother from Dame Fusti-Bunga,
Who troubled long time with a strangury,
Vented at last salt-water so abundantly,
As drowned the land twixt Sirixia and Vere,
Where steeples tops are only seen: he casts
Beyond the Moon, and will be greater yet
In spite of Don.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: You must abuse the maid
Beyond amends.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: But countenance the course
My Lord, and it may chance beside the mirth,
To work a reformation on the maiden,
Her fathers leave is granted, and thanks promised,
Our ends are harmless trials.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: I betray me secrets of such use.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Your Lordships humblest.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: A Melancholy grounded, and resolved,
Received into a habit, argues love,
Or deep impression of strong discontents,
In cases of these rarities a friend
Upon whose faith, and confidence, we may
Vent with security, our grief becomes
Oft times the best Physician, for admit
We find no remedy, we cannot miss
Advise in stead of comfort, and believe
It is an ease, Malfato, to disburden
Our souls of secret clogs, where they may find
A rest in pity, though not in redress.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Let all this sense be yielded to

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Perhaps you measure what I say, the common nature
Of an officious curiosity

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Not I Sir.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Or that other private ends
Sift your retirements --

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Under favour
Seignior Malfato, I am sent to crave
Your leisure, for a word or two in private.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To me! your mind

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: This letter will inform ye.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Letter? how is this? what is here?

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Speak ye to me sir?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Brave riddle: I will endeavour to unfold it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: How fares the Lord Adurni?

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Sure in health sir.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He is a noble Gentle-man; withal
Happy in his endeavours: the general voice
Sounds him for courtesy, behaviour, language,
And every fair demeanour, an example:
titles of honour add not to his worth,
Who is himself an honour to his titles.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You know from whence this comes.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Do ye laugh!
But that I must consider such as Spaniels,
To those who feed and cloth them, I would print
Thy panderism upon thy fore-head: there
Bear back that paper to the hell from whence
It gave thee thy directions, tell this Lord,
He ventured on a foolish policy,
In aiming at the scandal of my blood,
The trick is childish, base, say base.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: You wrong him.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Be wise Malfato.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Say, I know this whore.
She who sent this temptation, was wife
To his abused servant, and divorced
From poor Benatzi, senseless of the wrongs
That Madam Levidolche and Adurni
Might revel in their sports without control,
Secure, unchecked.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You range too wildly now,
Are too much inconsiderate.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I am
A gentleman free born, I never wore
The rags of any great man's looks, nor fed
Upon their after-meals; I never crouched
Unto the offal of an Office promised
Reward for long attendance, and then missed,
I read no difference between this huge,
This monstrous big word Lord, and Gentleman,
More than the title sounds; for ought I learn,
The latter is as noble as the first,
I am sure more ancient.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Let me tell you then,
You are too bitter, talk you know not what,
Make all men equals, and confound all course
Of order, and of Nature: this is madness.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: It is so; and I have reason to be mad:
Reason Aurelio, by my truth and hopes.
This wit Futelli brings a suit of love
From Lenidolche, one however masked
In colourable privacy, is famed
The Lord Adurnies pensioner, at least.
Am I a husband picked out for a strumpet,
For a cast suit of bawdry? Aurelio,
You are as I am, you could ill digest
The trial of a patience so unfit.
Be gone Futelli, do not mince one syllable
Of what you hear: another fetch like this
May tempt a peace to rage: so say, be gone.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: I shall report your answer.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What have I
Deserved to be so used? in colder blood
I do confess nobility requires
Duty and love, it is a badge of virtue,
By action first acquired, and next in rank
Unto anointed royalty wherein
Have I neglected distance, or forgot
Observance to superiors? sure my name
Was in the note mistook.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: We will consider the meaning of this mystery.

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.l: Not so,
Let them fear bondage who are slaves to fear,
The sweetest freedom is an honest heart.

div.head: Actus Secundus.

sp.speaker: Fvtelli.
sp.l: Dexterity and sufferance, brave Don,
Are Engines the pure politic must work with.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: We understand.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: In subtleties of war,
(I talk to ye now in your own occupation,
Your trade, or what you please) unto a Soldier,
Surprisal of an enemy by stratagem,
Or down-right cutting throats is all one thing.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Most certain: on, proceed.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: By way of parallel,
You drill or exercise your company,
(No matter which for terms) before you draw
Into the field, so in the feats of Courtship,
First choice is made of thoughts, behaviour, words,
The set of looks, the posture of the beard,
Besol as manus, cringes of the knee,
The very hums and ha's, thumps, and aye-me's.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: We understand all these: advance.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Then next,
Your enemy in face, your mistress (mark it)
Now you consult either to skirmish slightly,
That is careless amours, or to enter battle,
Then fall to open treaty, or to work
By secret spies or gold: here you corrupt
The Chambermaid, a fatal engine, or
Place there an Ambuses do, that is contract
With some of her near friends, for half her portion,
Or offer truce, and in the interim,
Run upon slaughter, it is a noble treachery,
That is swear and lie, steal her away: and to her
Cast caps, and cry Victoria, the field is
Thine own (my Don) she is thine.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: We do vouchsafe her.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Hold her then fast.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: As fast as can the arms
Of strong imagination hold her.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: No, she has skipped your hold, my imaginations eyes
Perceives she not endures the touch or sent
Of your war-over-worn habiliments,
Which I forgot in my instructions
To warn you of, therefore my warlike Don,
Apparel speedily your imagination
With a more courtly out-side.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: It is soon done.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: As soon as said, in all the clothes thou hast,
More than that walking wardrobe on thy back.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Imagine first our rich Mockado doublet,
With our cut cloth of gold sleeves, and our quellio,
Our Diamond buttoned Callamancho hose,
Our plume of Ostrich, with the embroidered scarf
The Duchess Infantasgo rolled our arm in.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Ayethis is brave indeed.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Our Cloak whose cape is
Larded with pearls, which the Indian Iacquies
Presented to our countryman De Cortez,
For ransom of his life, rated in value
At thirteen thousand pistolets, the guerdon
Of our achievement, when we rescued
The Infanta from the Bore in single duel,
Near to the Austrian forest with this rapier,
This only, very, naked, single rapier.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Top and top-gallant brave,

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Before our Amoretta like the issue
Of our progenitors.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Imagine so,
And that this rich suit of imagination,
Is on already now (which is most probable
As that apparel) here stands your Amoretta,
Make your approach and court her.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Lustre of beauty,
Not to affright your tender soul with horror,
We may descend to tales of peace and love,
Soft whispers fitting Ladies closets, for
Thunder of cannon, roaring smoke and fire,
As if hells maw had vomited confusion,
The clash of steel, the neighs of barbed Steeds,
Wounds spouting blood, towns capering in the air,
Castles pushed down, and Cities ploughed with swords,
Become great Guzmans Oratory best,
Who though victorious, and during life
Must be: yet now grants parley to thy smiles.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: 'sfoot, Don, you talk too big, you make her tremble,
Do you not see it imaginarily?
I do as plainly as you saw the death
Of the Austrian Bore, she rather hears
Of feasting than of fighting, take her that way.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Yes we will feast my queen, my empress saint,
Shalt taste no delicates but what are dressed
With costlier spices than the Arabian bird
Sweetens her funeral bed with, we will riot
With every change of meats; which may renew
Our blood unto a spring, so pure, so high,
That from our pleasures shall proceed a race
Of sceptre-bearing princes, who at once
Must reign in every quarter of the globe.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Can more be said by one that feeds on herring
And garlic constantly?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Yes we will feast.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Enough, she is taken, and will love you now,
As well in buff, as your imagined bravely,
Your dainty ten times dressed buff, with this language
(Bold man of arms) shall win upon her, doubt not
Beyond all silken puppetry, think no more
Of your mockadoes, calaminchaes, quellios,
Pearl larded capes and diamond buttoned breeches,
Leave such poor out-side helps to puling lovers,
Such as Fulgoso your weak rival is,
That starveling brained-companion appear you
At first (at least) in your own warlike fashion:
I pray be ruled, and change not a thread about you.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: The humour takes (for I sir, am a man
Affects not shifts) I will adventure thus.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Why so you carry her from all the world,
I am proud my stars designed me out an instrument
In such an hie employment.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: gravely spoken,
You may be proud of it --

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: What is lost is lost,
Money is trash, and Ladies are etceteras
Play is play; luck is luck, fortunes an I know what,
You see the worst of me, and what is all this now?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: A very spark (I vow) you will be styled,
Fulgoso the invincible, but did
The fair Spinella lose an equal part
How much in all do ye say?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Bare threescore ducats,
Thirty a piece, we need not care who know it
She played, I went her half walked by and whistled
After my usual manner thus -- unmoved
As no such thing had ever been as it were,
Although I saw the winners share my money
His lordship, and an honest gentleman
Pursed it, but not so merrily as I
Whistled it off -- whistles

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: A noble confidence.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Do ye note your rival.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: With contempt I do.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I can forgo things nearer than my gold,
Allied to my affections, and my blood;
Yea honour, as it were, with the same kind.
Of careless confidence, and come off fairly
Too as it were.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: But not your love, Fulgoso.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: No, she is inherent, and mine own past loosing.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: It tickles me to think with how much state,
You, as it were, did run at tilt in love
Before your Amoretta.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Broke my lance.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Of wit, of wit.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I mean so as it were
And laid flat on her back, both horse and woman.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Right as it were.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: What else man, as it were.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Did you do this to her, dare you to vaunt
You triumph we being present? um, ha, um.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: What think you Don, of this brave man?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: A ma?
It is some truss of reeds, or empty cask,
In which the wind with whistling sports itself

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Beat up Sir, he is your rival, budge not from him
An inch, your grounds are honour.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Stoutly ventured, Don, hold him to it.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: protest a fine conceit,
A very fine conceit, and thus I told her,
That for mine own part, if she liked me, so,
If not, not; for my duck or do said I,
It is no fault of mine, that I am noble,
Grant it; another may be noble too,
And then we are both one noble better still
Habs-nabs good wink and choose, if one must have her,
The other goes without her, best of all,
My spirit is too high, to fight for woman,
I am too full of mercy to be angry,
A foolish generous quality, from which
No might of man can beat I am I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Hast thou a spirit then ha? speakes thy weapon
Toledo language, Bilbo, or dull Pisa?
If an Italian blade, or spanish metal,
Be brief, we challenge answer.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Famous Don.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: What does he talk? my weapon speaks no language,
It is a dutch iron truncheon.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Dutch?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: And if need be,
It will maul one's hide, in spite of who says nay

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Dutch to a Spaniard, hold me.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Hold me too
Sirra if thou art my friend, for I love no fighting,
Yet hold me least in pity I fly off,
If I must fight, I must; in a scurvy quarrel
I defy he is and she is, twit me with dutch?
Hang dutch and french, hang spanish and Italians,
Christians and Turks pew-waw; all is one to me,
I know what is what, I know on which side
My bread is buttered.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Buttered? dutch again?
You come not with intention to affront us.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Front me no fronts, if thou beest angry squabble
Here is my defence, and thy destruction --
If friends shake hands, and go with me to dinner.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: We will embrace the motion, it doth relish,
The Cavalier treats on terms of honour,
Peace is not to be balked on fair conditions.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Still Don is Don the great.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: He shows the greatness
Of his vast stomach in the quick embracement
Of the others dinner.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: It was the ready means to catch his friendship.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: You are a pair of worthies,
That make the nine no wonder.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Now since fate
Ordains that one of two must be the man,
The man of men which must enjoy alone
Loves darling Amoretta, both take liberty
To show himself before her, without cross
Of interruption, one of the other: he
Whose sacred mystery of earthly blessings
Crowns the pursuit; be happy.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: And till then, live brothers in society.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: We are fast.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I vow a match: I will feast the Don today
And fast with him tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Fair conditions.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Futelli and Piero, follow speedily.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: My Lord we wait ye.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: We shall soon return.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: What is that? I saw a sound.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: A voice for certain.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: It named a Lord.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Here are Lords too, we take it,
We carry blood about us, rich and haughty,
As any the twelve Caesars.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Gulls or Moguls,
Tag, rag, or other, Hoger-Mogen vanden
Skip-Iacks, or Chouses. Whoo! the brace are flinched,
The pair of shavers are sneaked from us, Don.
Why? what are we?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: The valiant will stand to it

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: So say I, we will eat and drink, and squander,
Till all do split again.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Match on with greediness.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You cannot answer what a general tongue
Objects against your folly, I may curse
The interest you lay claim to in my blood,
Your mother my dear niece did die, I thought
Too soon, but she is happy, had she lived;
Till now, and known the vanities of your life
Hath dealt in, she had wished herself a grave
Before a timely hour.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Sir, consider,
My sex, were I mankind, my sword should quit
A wounded honour, and reprieve a name
From injury, by printing on their bosoms
Some deadly Character, whose drunken surfeits
Vomit such base aspersions, as I am
Scorn and contempt is virtue: my desert
Stands far above their malice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Levidolche, hypocrisy puts on a holy robe,
Yet never changeth nature: call to mind,
How in your girls days you fell forsooth
In love, and married, married (hark ye) whom
A trencher-waiter, shrewd preferment: but
Your childhood then excused that fault: for so
Footmen have run away with lusty heirs,
And stable-grooms reached to some fair ones chambers.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Pray let not me be bandied sir, and baffled
By your intelligence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So touched to the quick,
Fine mistress, I will then rip up at length
The progress of your infancy, in colour
Of disagreement you must be divorced,
Were so, and I must countenance the reasons
On better hopes I did, nay took you home,
Provided you my care, nay justified
Your alteration, joyed to entertain
Such visitants of worth and rank, is tendered
Civil respects; but then, even then --

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: What then?
Sweet uncle do not spare me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye more shame
To fear my hospitality was bawd
And (name it so) to your unchaste desires,
Than you to hear and know it.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Whose whore am I?
For that is your plainest meaning.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Were you modest,
The word you uttered last would force a blush.
Adurni is a bounteous Lord, it is said,
He parts with gold and jewels like a free
And liberal purchaser, he wriggles in
To Ladies pleasures by a right of pension;
But you know none of this:
You are grown a Tavern talk,
Matter for Fiddlers songs, I toil to build
The credit of my family, and you
To pluck up the foundation, even this morning
Before the common Council, young Malfato
Convented for some lands he held; supposed
Belonged to certain Orphans, as I questioned
His tenure in particulars, he answered,
My worship needed not to flaw his right:
For if the humour held him, he could make
A jointure to my over-living Niece,
Without oppression, bad me tell her too,
She was a kind young soul, and might in time
Be sued to by a loving man, no doubt.
Here was a jolly breakfast.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Uncles are privileged
More than our parents, some wise man in state
Hath rectified, no doubt, your knowledge sir,
Whiles all the policy for public business,
Was spent -- for want of matter, I by chance
Fell into grave discourse; but by your leave,
I from a strangers table rather wish
To earn my bread, than from a friends by gift,
Be daily subject to unfit reproves.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, come, to the point.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: All the curses
Due to a ravisher of sober truth,
Dam up their graceless mouths.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now you turn rampant,
Just in the wenches trim and garb, these prayers
Speak your devotions purely.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Sir, alas,
What would you have me do? I have no Orators,
More than my tears, to plead my innocence,
Since you forsake me, and are pleased to lend
An open ear against my honest fame.
Would all their spite could harry my contents
Unto a desperate ruin; O dear goodness,
There is a right for wrongs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There is, but first
Sir in commission on your own defects,
Accuse yourself: be your own Jury, Judge,
And executioner, I make no sport
Of my vexation.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: All the short remains
Of undesired life, shall only speak
The extremitie of penance: your opinion
Enjoins it too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Enough; thy tears prevail
Against credulity.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: My miseries,
As in a glass, present me the rent face
Of an unguided youth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No more -- Trelcatio,
Some business speeds you hither.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: Happy news,
Seignior Martino, pray your ear; my nephew
Auria hath done brave service: and I hear
(Let us be exceeding private) is returned
High in the Duke of Florences respects,
It is said, but make no words that he has firked
And mumbled the roguey-Turks.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why would you know
His merits so unknown?

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: I am not yet
Confirmed at full, withdraw, and you shall read
All what this paper talks.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So; Levidolche, you know our mind,
Be cheerful, come Trelcatio,
Causes of joy or grief, do seldom happen
Without companions, near thy resolutions
Have given another birth to my contents.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Even so, wise uncle, much good do ye -- discovered!
I could fly out, mix vengeance with my love,
Unworthy man Malfato, my good Lord
My hot in blood, rare Lord, grows cold too, well
Rise dotage into rage, and sleep no longer;
Affection turned to hatred, threatens mischief.

div.stage: Exit. Enter Piero, Amoretta, Futilli, and Castana.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: In the next gallery you may behold
Such living pictures Lady, such rich pieces,
Of Kings, and Queens, and Princes, that you would think
They breath, and smile upon ye.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.l: Ha, they crownthes,
Great crownthes of gold upon their heads.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Pure gold,
Drawn all in state.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.l: How many horses pray
Are with their Chariots?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Sixteen, some twenty.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My sister wherefore left we her alone?
Where stays she gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Viewing the rooms,
It is like you will meet her in the gallery.
This house is full of curiosities,
Most fit for Ladies sights.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.l: Of princesses is a fine sight.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Good, let us find her.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Sweet Ladies this way; see the doors sure.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Doubt not.

lg.l: Pleasures, Beauty, Youth attend ye.
Whiles the spring of nature lasteth,
Love and melting thoughts attend ye
Use the time, ere winter hasteth.
Active blood, and free delight,
Place and privacy invite.
Do do! be kind as fair,
Lose not opportunity for air.
She is cruel that denies it,
Bounty best appears in granting,
Stealth of sport as soon supplies it,
Whiles the dues of love are wanting.
Here is the sweet exchange of bliss,
When each whisper proves a kiss.
In the game are felt no pains,
For in all the looser gains.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Plead not fair creature without sense of pity
So uncompassionately against a service,
In nothing faulty more than pure obedience,
My honours and my fortunes are led captives
In triumph by your all-commanding beauty,
And if you ever felt the power of love,
The rigour of an uncontrolled passion,
The tyranny of thoughts consider mine,
In some proportion, by the strength of yours,
Thus may you yield and conquer.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Do not study
(My Lord) to apparel folly in the steed
Of costly colours, henceforth cast off far
Far from your noblest nature, the contempt
Of goodness, and be gentler to your fame,
By purchase of a life to grace your story.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Dear, how sweetly
Reproof droops from that balmy spring your breath,
Now could I read a lecture of my griefs
Un-earth a mine of Jewels at your foot,
Command a golden shower to rain down,
Impoverish every Kingdom of the east,
Which traffics richest clothes, and silks; would you
Vouchsafe one, unspleened chiding to my riot,
Else such a sacrifice can but beget
Suspicion of returns, to my devotion,
In mercenary blessings, for that saint
To whom I vow myself, must never want
Fit offerings to her altar.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Auria, Auria,
Fight not for name abroad, but come my husband,
Fight for thy wife at home.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: O never cank
(Dear cruelty) one that is sworn your creature,
Amongst your countries enemies, I use.
No force, but humble words, delivered from
A tongue that is secretary to my heart.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: How poorly some, tame to their wild desires,
Fawn on abuse of virtue, pray my Lord,
Make not your house my prison.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Grant a freedom,
To him who is the bondman to your beauty.

div.stage: Enter Aurelio, Castanna, Amoretta, Futilli, and Piero.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Keep back ye close contrivers of false pleasures,
Or I shall force ye back -- can it be possible
Locked up and singly too, chaste hospitality
A banquet in a bed-chamber; Adurni!
Dishonourable man.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: What sees this rudeness,
That can broach scandal here.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: For you hereafter,
O woman, lost to every brave report,
Thy wronged Auria is come home with glory,
Prepare a welcome to uncrown the greatness
Of his prevailing fates,

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Whiles you belike,
Are furnished with some news for entertainment
Which must become your friendship to be knit
More fast betwixt your souls, by my removal,
Both from his heart and memory.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Rich conquest,
To triumph on a Ladies injured fame,
Without a proof or warrant.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Have I life Sir,
Faith, Christianity?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Put me on the rack,
The wheel, or the gallies, if --

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Peace factors,
In merchandise of scorn, your sounds are deadly,
Castanna, I could pity your consent
To such ignoble practice, but I find.
Course fortunes easily seduced, and herein
All claim to goodness ceases.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Use your tyranny.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: What rests behind for me, out with it.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Horror,
Becoming such a forfeit of obedience,
Hope not that any falsity in friendship
Can palliate a broken faith, it dares not
Leave in thy prayers (fair vow-breaking want on)
To dress thy soul new, whose purer whiteness
Is sullied by thy change, from truth to folly.
A fearful storm is hovering, it will fall,
No shelter can avoid it, let the guilty
Sink under their own ruin.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: How unmanly
His anger threatens mischief!

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.l: Whom, I prithee,
Doth the man speak to?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Lady, be not moved,
I will stand Champion for your honour, hazard
All what is dearest to me.

sp.speaker: Spin.
sp.l: Mercy heaven!
Champion for me, and Auria living? Auria?
He lives, and for my guard my innocence
As free as are my husbands clearest thoughts,
Shall keep off vain constructions, I must beg
Your charities; sweet sister, yours to leave me,
I need no fellows now: let me appear,
Or mine own lawyer, or in open court
(Like some forsaken client) in my suit
Be cast for want of honest plea -- O misery.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Her resolution is violent, quickly follow,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: By no means (sir) you have followed her already,
I fear with too much ill success in trial,
Of unbecoming courtesies; your welcome
Ends in so sad a farewell.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: I will stand
The roughness of the encounter, like a gentleman,
And wait ye to your homes, what ere befall me.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Fulgoso.
sp.l: I say, Don, brother mine, win her and we are her.
And so will I; if it be my luck, to lose her,
I lose a pretty wench, and there is the worst of it.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Wench said ye, most mechanically? faugh!
Wench is your trull, your blows, your dowdy, but
(Sir brother) he who names my Queen of love
Without his bonnet veiled, or saying grace,
As at Some paranymphall feast, is rude,
Nor versed in literature, Dame Amoretta,
Lo, I am sworn thy Champion.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: So am I too.
Can as occasion serves, if she turn scurvy,
Un-swear myself again, and never change colours.
Pish man, the best, though call them, ladies, madams,
Fairs, fines, and honeys, are but flesh and blood,
And now and then too, when the fits come on them,
Will prove themselves but flirts, and tirliry pufkins.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Our choler must advance.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Dost long for a beating?
Shall us try a slash, here is that shall do it: I will tap
A gallon of thy brains, and fill thy hogshead
With two of wine for it.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Not in friendship brother,

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Or whistle thee into an ague; hang it,
Be sociable: drink till we roar and scratch;
Then drink ourselves asleep again. The fashion!
Thou dost not know the fashion.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Her fair eyes,
Like to a pair of pointed beams drawn from
The Suns most glorious Orb, does dazzle sight,
Audacious to gaze there; then over those
A several bow of jet securely twines
In semicircles; under them two banks
Of roses red and white, divided by
An arch of polished Ivory, surveying
A temple from whence Oracles proceed,
More gracious than Apollos, more desired
Than amorous songs of Poets, softly tuned.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Hey day, what is this?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: O, but those other parts, all --

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: All: Hold there, I bar play under board,
My part yet lies therein; you never saw
The things you wire-draw thus.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: I have dreamed
Of every part about her, can lay open
Her several inches, as exactly (mark it)
As if I had took measure with a compass,
A rule, or yard, from head to foot.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: O rare,
And all this in a dream.

div.stage: Enter Benatzi as an outlaw. Levidolche above.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: A very dream.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: My waking brother Soldier is turned
Into a sleeping Carpenter or Taylor,
Which goes for half a man -- what is he? bear up?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Death of reputation, the wheel, strappado, galles,
Rack, are ridiculous fopperies; goblins to
Fright babies: poor lean-souled rogues, they
Will swoon at the scar of a pin: one tear
Dropped from their harlots eyes, breeds earth-quakes
In their bones.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Bless us, a monster patched of dagger bombast,
His eyes like Copper-basins, he has changed
Hair with a shag dog.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Let us then avoid him,
Or stand upon our guard; the foe approaches.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Cut-throats by the score abroad, come home, and rot in
fripperies, brave man at arms. Go turn pander do, stalk for a
mess of warm broth: damnable, honourable cuts are but badges
for a fool to vaunt, the raw ribbed Apothecary poisons cum privilegio,
and is paid. O the common-wealth of beasts is most politically
ordered.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Brother, we will keep aloof, there is no valour
In tugging with a man fiend

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I defy him.
It gabbles like I know not what, believe it,
The fellows a shrewd fellow at a pink.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Look else; the Lion roars, and the spaniel fawns.
Down Cur, the Badger bribes the Unicorn,
That a Jury may not pass upon his pillage: here the Bear fees the
Wolf, for he will not howl gratis, beasts call pleading howling.
So then, there the Horse complains of the Apes rank-riding: the
Jockey makes mouths, but is fined for it: the Stag is not jeered
by the Monkey for his horns: the Ass by the hare for his burthen:
The Ox by the Leopard for his yoke, nor the Goat by the Ram,
for his beard, only the Fox wraps himself warm in Beaver,
bids the Cat mouse, the Elephant toil, the Boar gather acorns,
whiles he grins, feeds fat, tells tales, laughs at all, and sleeps
safe at the Lions feet. -- Save ye people.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Why save thee too, if thou beest of heavens making:
What art? -- Fear nothing Don, we have our blades,
Are metal men ourselves, try us who dare.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p:
Our brother speaks our mind, think what you please
of it.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
A match: observe well this switch; with this only switch
have I bashed out the brains of thirteen Turks to the dozen for a
breakfast.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: What man? thirteen? is it possible thou liest not?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
I was once a Scholar, then I begged without pity: from
thence I practised law, there a scruple of conscience popped me over
the bar: a Soldier I turned a while, but could not procure the
letter of preferment. Merchant I would be, and a glut of land-rats
gnawed me to the bores; would have bought an office, but
the places with reversions were catched up: offered to pass into the
Court, and wanted trust for clothes; was lastly, for my good parts
pressed into the Gallies, taken prisoner, redeemed amongst other
slaves by your gay great man, they call him Auria: and am
now I know not who, where, or what. How do ye like me?
say.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: A shaver of all trades; what course of life
Dost mean to follow next? ha? speak thy mind.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Nor be thou daunted fellow: we ourselves
Have felt the frowns of fortune in our days.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I want extremely, exceedingly, hideously.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Take that, enjoy it freely, wisely use it.
The advantage of thy fate, and know the giver.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Hoy da, a purse in troth who dropped, stay, stay,
Umh; have we gypsies here? O mine is safe
Is it your purse, brother Don?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Not mine, I seldom
Wear such unfashionable trash about me.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Hast any money in it, honest blade?
A bots on empty purses.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: We defy them.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Stand from about me, as you are mortal, you are dull
clod-pated lumps of mire and garbage. This is the land of Fairies,
Imperial Queen of Elves, I do crouch to thee, vow my services,
my blood, my sinews to thee, sweet sovereign of largess, and
liberality -- a French Taylor neat; Persian Cook; dainty!
Greek Wines; rich Flanders Mares; stately Spanish Salads, poignant,
Venetian, wanton, ravishing, English Bawd unmatchable sirs I
am fitted.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: All these thy followers, miserable pygmies
Prate sense and do not be mad, I like thy humour,
It is pretty odd, and so as one might say,
I care not greatly if I entertain thee,
Dost want a master? if thou dost I am for thee
Else choose, and sneak up; pish I scorn to flinch man.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Forsake not fair advancement, money certes
Will fleet and drop off, like a cozening friend,
Who holds it, holds a slippery Eel by the tail,
Unless he gripe it fast, be ruled by counsel.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Excellent, what place shall I be admitted to?
Chamber, wardrobe, cellar, or stable.

sp.l: Why one and all, thou art welcome, let us shake hands on it
Thy name?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Parado Sir

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: The great affairs
I shall employ thee most in will be news,
And telling what is a clock, for ought I know yet.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
It is sir to speak punctually some hour and half
Eight three thirds of two seconds of one minute over at most, Sir

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I do not ask thee now, or if I did
We are not much the wiser, and for news --

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Auria, the fortunate is this day to be received with great
solemnity at the city counsel house, the streets are already thronged
with lookers on.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: That is well remembered, brother Don let us trudge,
Or we shall come too late.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: By no means, brother.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Wait close my ragged new-come.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: As your shadows.

div.stage: Exit. Enter Auria, Adurni, Martino, Trelcatio, Aurelio, Piero, and Futilli.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Your favours with these honours, speak your bounties
And though the low deserts of my success
Appear in your constructions fair and goodly,
Yet I attribute to a noble cause,
Not my abilities, the thanks due to them,
The Duke of Florence hath too highly prized
My duty in my service, by example,
Rather to cherish and encourage virtue,
spirits of action, than to crown the issue
Of feeble undertakings, whiles my life
Can stand in use I shall no longer rate it
In value than it stirs to pay that debt,
I owe my country for my birth and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Which to make good, our state of Genoa
Not willing that a native of her own,
So able for her safety, should take pension
From any other Prince; hath cast upon you
The government of Corsica.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: Adds thereto
Besides the allowance yearly due, for ever
To you and to your heirs, the full revenue
Belonging to Savona; with the office
Of Admiral of Genoa.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: Presenting
By my hands, from their public treasury,
A thousand Ducats.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But they limit only
One month of stay, for your dispatch, no more.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: In all your great attempts, may you grow thrifty.
Secure, and prosperous.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: If you please to rank,
Amongst the humblest one that shall attend
Instructions under your command, I am
Ready to wait the charge.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: O still the state
Engageth me her creature with the burthen
Unequal for my weakness, to you gentlemen
I will prove friendly honest, of all mindful.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: In memory (my Lord, such is your style now)
Of your late fortunate exploits, the counsel
Amongst their general acts, have registered
The great Dukes letters, witness of your merit
To stand in characters upon record.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Load upon load let not my want of modesty
Trespass against good manners, I must study
Retirement to compose this weighty business
And moderately digest so large a plenty.
For fear it swell unto a surfeit.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: May I
be bold to press a visit?

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: At your pleasure,
Good time of day, and peace,
Oes: health to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: What of Spinella yet?

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Quite lost no prints,
Or any tongue of tracing her, how ever
Matters are huddled up: I doubt my Lord
Her husband carries little peace about him.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: fall danger what fall can, she is a goodness
Above temptation, more to be adored
Than sifted; I am to blame sure.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Levidolche,
For her part too, laughed at Malfatos frenzy
(Just so she termed it) but for you (my Lord)
She said she thanked your charity, which lent
Her crooked soul, before it left her body,
Some respite, wherein it might learn again
The means of growing straight.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: She has found mercy,
Which I will seek, and sue for.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: You are happy.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Count of Savona, Genoas Admiral,
Lord governor of Corsica, enrolled
A Worthy of my country, sought and sued to
Praised, courted, flattered; sure this bulk of mine,
Tails in the size a timpani of greatness
Puffs up too monstrously my narrow chest,
How surely dost thou malice, these extremes,
Uncomfortable man? when I was needy,
Cast naked on the flats of barren pity,
Abated to an ebb so low, that boys
A Cock-horse frisked about me, without plunge
You could chat gravely then, in formal tones,
Reason most paradoxically; now
Contempt and wilful grudge at my uprising
becalms your learned noise.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Such flourish Auria,
Flies with so swift a gale, as it will waste
Thy sudden joys into a faithless harbour.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Canst mutter mischief, I observed your dullness
Whiles the whole ging crowd to me hark my triumphs
Are echoed under every roof, the air
Is straightened with the sound, there is not room
Enough to brace them in, but not a thought
Doth pierce into the grief that cabins hear,
Here through a creek a little in-let crawls,
A flake no bigger than a sisters thread,
Which sets the region of my heart a fire.
I had a kingdom once, but am deposed
From all that royalty of blessed content,
by a confederacies twixt love and frailty.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: glories in public view, but add to misery,
Which travails in unrest at home.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: At home?
That home Aurelio speaks of, I have lost,
And which is worse, when I have rolled about,
Toiled like a pilgrim, round this globe of earth,
Wearied with care, and overworn with age,
Lodged in the grave, I am not yet at home,
There rots but half of me, the other part
Sleeps, heaven knows where, would she and I my wife,
I mean, but what alas talk I of wife,
The woman, would we had together fed
On any out-cast parings, course and mouldy,
Not lived divided thus, I could have begged
For both, for it had been pity she should ever
Have felt so much extremity.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: This is not
Patience required in wrongs of such vile nature,
You pity her, think rather on revenge.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Revenge! For what? (uncharitable friend)
On whom? let us speak a little pray with reason,
You found Spinella in Adurnies house,
It is like he gave her welcome very likely,
Her sister and another with her, so
Invited, nobly done; but he with her
Privately chambered, he deserves no wife
Of worthy quality, who dares not trust
Her virtue in the proofs of any danger.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: But I broke ope the doors upon them.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Marry, it was a slovenly presumption,
And punishable by a sharpe rebuke.
I tell you sir, I in my younger growth,
Have by the stealth of privacy enjoyed
A Ladies closet, where to have profaned
That shrine of chastity and innocence,
With one unhallowed word, would have exiled
The freedom of such favour into scorn.
Had any he alive then ventured there,
With foul construction, I had stamped the justice
Of my unguilty truth upon his heart.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Adurni might have done the like, but that
The conscience of his fault in coward blood,
blushed at the quick surprisal.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: O fie, fie.
How ill some argue in their sour reproof,
Against a party liable to law:
For had that Lord offended with that creature,
Her presence would have doubled every strength
Of man in him, and justified the forfeit
Of noble shame, else it was enough in both
With a smile only to correct your rudeness.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: It is well you make such use of neighbours courtesy,
Some kind of beasts are tame, and hug their injuries:
Such way leads to a fame too.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Not uncivilly, though violently, friend.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Wherefore then, think ye,
Can she absent herself, if she be blameless?
You grant of course, your triumphs are proclaimed,
And I in person told her your return.
Where lies she hid the while?

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: That rests for answer
In you, now I come to ye, we have exchanged
bosoms, Aurelio, from our years of childhood,
Let me acknowledge with whatpride I own
A man so faithful, honest, fast, my friend:
He whom if I speak fully, never failed
by teaching trust to me, to learn of mine,
I wished myself thine equal; if I aimed
A wrong, it was in an envy of thy goodness,
So dearly witness with me my integrity,
I laid thee up to heart, that from my love,
My wife was but distinguished in her sex,
Give back that holy signature of friendship,
Canceled, defaced, plucked off, or I shall urge,
Accounts scored on the tally of my vengeance,
Without all former complements.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Do ye imagine
I fawn upon your fortunes, or intrude
Upon the hope of bettering my estate,
That you cashier me at a minutes warning?
No, Auria, I dare vie with your respects,
Put both into the balance, and the poise
Shall make a settled stand, perhaps the proffer,
So frankly vowed at your departure first
Of settling me a partner in your purchase,
Leads you into opinion of some ends
Of mercenary falsehood, yet such wrong
Lest suites a noble soul.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: By all my sorrows,
The mention is too course.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Since then the occasion
Presents our discontinuance, use your liberty:
For my part I am resolute to die
The same my life professed me.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Pish, your faith
Was never in suspicion; but consider,
Neither the Lord nor Lady, nor the bawd,
Which shuffled them together, opportunity
Have fastened stain on my unquestioned name,
My friends rash indiscretion was the bellows
Which blew the coal now kindled to a flame,
Will light his slander to all wandering eyes.
Some men in giddy zeal over-do that office
They catch at, of whose number is Aurelio:
For I am certain, certain it had been
Impossible, had you stood wisely silent,
but my Spinella, trembling on her knee,
Would have accused her breach of truth, have begged
A speedy execution on her trespass,
Then with a justice lawful as the magistrates,
Might I have drawn my sword against Adurni,
Which now is sheathed and rusted in the scabbard;
Good thanks to your cheap providence, once more
I make demand -- my wife -- you -- sir.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: The noise affrights not me, threaten your enemies,
And prove a valiant tongue man -- now must follow,
by way of method, the exact condition
Of rage which runs to mutiny in friendship.
Auria come on, this weapon looks not pale
At fight of that again hear and believe it,
What I have done, was well done and well meant;
Twenty times over, were it new to do.
I would do it and do it, and boast the pains religious;
Yet since you shake me off, I slightly value
Other severity.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Honour and duty
Stand my compurgators, never did passion
Purpose ungentle usage of my sword,
Against Aurelio, let me rather want
My hands, nay friend, a heart than ever suffer
Such dotage enter here, if I must lose
Spinella, let me not proceed to misery,
by loosing my Aurelio, we through madness,
Frame strange conceits, in our discoursing brains,
And prate of things as we pretend they were,
Join help to mine (goodman) and let us listen
After this straying soul, and till we find her,
bear our discomfort quietly.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: So doubtless,
She may be soon discovered.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: That is spoke cheerfully.
Why there is a friend now, -- Auria and Aurelio
At odds O it cannot be, must not, and shall not --
But look Castannas here, -- welcome fair figure
Of a choice Jewel, locked up in a cabinet,
More precious than the public view should sully.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sir how you are informed, or on what terms
Of prejudice against my course, or custom,
Opinion sways your confidence, I know not
Much anger, if my fears persuade not falsely,
Sits on this gentleman's stern brow, yet sir,
If an unhappy maids word may find credit,
As I wish harm to no body on earth,
So would all good folks may wish none to me.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: None does sweet sister.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: If they do, dear heaven
Forgive them is my prayer, but perhaps,
You might conceive (and yet methinks you should not)
How I am faulty in my sisters absence,
Indeed it is nothing so, nor was I knowing
Of any private speech my Lord intended,
Save civil entertainment, pray what hurt
Can fall out in discourse, if it be modest?
Sure noble men will show that they are such
With those of their own rank, and that was all
My sister can be charged with.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Is it not friend, an excellent maid?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Deserves the best of fortunes;
I ever spoke her virtuous.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: With your leave,
You used most cruel language to my sister,
Enough to fright her wits, not very kind
To me myself, she sighed when you were gone,
Desired no creature else should follow her;
And in good truth, I was so full of weeping,
I marked not well which way she went.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Staid she not
Within the house then?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Lass not she -- Aurelio
Was passing rough.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Strange! No where to be found out.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Not yet, but on my life, ere many hours,
I shall hear from her.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Shalt thou? worthy maid,
Thou hast brought to my sick heart a cordial -- friend
Good news -- most sweet Castanna.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: May it prove so.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
The paper in the purse for my directions appointed this
the place, the time now, here dance I attendance -- she is come
already.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Parado, so I over heard you named.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
A mushroom sprung up in a minute, by the sun-shine of
your benevolent grace, liberality and hospitable compassion (most
magnificent beauty) have long since lain bed-rid in the ashes of the
old world till now, your illustrious charity hath raked up the dead
embers by giving life to a worm inevitably devoted yours as you
shall please to new shape me.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: A grateful man (it seems) where gratitude
Has harbour; other furniture becoming
Accomplished qualities must needs inhabit,
What country claims your birth?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
None, I was born at sea, as my mother was in passage
from cape Ludugory to cape Clagliary toward Affrick in Sardinia,
was bred up in Aquilastro, and at years put myself in service under
the Spanish Viceroy: till I was taken prisoner by the Turks.
I have tasted in my days handsome store of good and bad, and am
thankful for both.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: You seem the issue then of honest parents.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Reputed no less: many children oftentimes inherit their
lands who peradventure never begot them: my mothers husband
was a very old man at my birth, but no man is too old to father his
wives child, your servant I am sure I will ever prove myself
entirely.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Dare you be secret?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: And sudden.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: But withal, sure of hand, and spirit.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: I use not many words, the time prevents them,
A man of quality has robbed mine honour.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: name him.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Adurni.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: He shall bleed.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Malfato contemned my proffered love.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yoke them in death -- what is my reward?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Propose it, and enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: You for my wife.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Nothing else, deny me.
And I will betray your counsels to your ruin;
Else do the feat courageously -- consider.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: I do dispatch the task I have enjoined,
Then claim my promise.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No such matter, pretty one,
We will marry first -- or -- farewell.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Stay, examine
From my confession what a plague thou drawest
Into thy bosom, though I blush to say it,
Know I have without sense of shame, or honour,
Forsook a lawful marriage bed, to dally
Between Adurnis arms.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This Lords.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: The same; more not content with him I courted,
A newer pleasure, but was there refused by him I named so late.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Malfato.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Right, am henceforth resolutely bent to print
My follies on their hearts, then change my life
For some rare penance, canst thou love me now?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Better I do believe it is possible you may mend,
All this breaks off no bargain.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Accept my hand, with this a faith as constant
As vows can urge, not shall my haste prevent
This contract, which death only must divorce.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Settle the time.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Meet here tomorrow night,
We will determine further, as behoves us.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How is my new love called?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Levidolche, be confident, I bring a worthy portion;
But you will fly off.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Not I, by all that is noble,
A kiss -- farewell -- dear fate.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Love is sharpe sighted
And can pierce through the cunning of disguises,
False pleasures I cashier ye, fair truth welcome.

div.head: Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Malfato.
sp.l: Here you are safe, (sad cousin) if you please
May over-say the circumstance of what
You late discoursed, mine ears are gladly open,
For I myself am in such hearty league
With solitary thoughts, that pensive language
Charms my attention.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: But my husbands honours,
By how much more in him they sparkle clearly
by so much more they tempt belief to credit
The wrack and ruin of my injured name.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why cousin should the earth cleave to the roots,
The seas and heavens be mingled in disorder,
Your purity with unaffrighted eyes
Might wait the uproar, it is the guilty trembles
At horrors, not the innocent, you are cruel
In censuring a liberty allowed.
Speak freely, gentle cousin, was Adurni
Importunately wanton?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Of entertainment, else not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Not the boldness
Of an uncivil courtship.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: What that meant,
I never understood, I have at once
Set bars between my best of earthly joys,
And best of men, so excellent a man
As lives without comparison, his love
To me was matchless.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yet put case, sweet cousin,
That I could name a creature, whose affection
Followed your Auria in the height: affection
To you; even to Spinella, true and settled,
As ever Auria's was, can, is, or will be.
You may not chide the story.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Fortunes minions
Are flattered, not the miserable.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Listen to a strange tale, which thus the author sighed,
A kinsman of Spinella (so it runs)
Her fathers sisters son, some time before
Auria the fortunate possessed her beauties,
Became enamoured of such rare perfections,
As she was stored with, fed his idle hopes
With possibilities of lawful conquest,
Proposed each difficulty in pursuit
Of what his vain supposal styled his own,
Found in the argument one only flaw
Of conscience, by the nearness of their bloods,
Unhappy scruple, easily dispensed with,
Had any friends advice resolved the doubt.
Still on he loved, and loved, and wished, and wished,
Eftsoon began to speak, yet soon broke off,
And still the fondling durst not, cause he durst not.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: It was wonderful,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Exceeding wonderful,
Beyond all wonder, yet it is known for truth,
After her marriage, when remained not ought
Of expectation to such fruitless dotage.
His reason then, now, then could not reduce
The violence of passion, though he vowed
Never to unlock that secret, scarce to her
Herself, Spinella, and withal resolved,
Not to come near her presence, but to avoid
All opportunities how ever proffered.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: An understanding dulled by the infelicity
Of constant sorrow, is not apprehensive
In pregnant novelty, my ears receive
The words you utter, cousin, but my thoughts
Are fastened on another subject.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Can you embrace, so like a darling, your own woes,
And play the tyrant with a partner in them?
Then I am thankful for advantage, urged
By fatal and enjoined necessity,
To stand up in defence of injured virtue,
Will against any, I except no quality,
Maintain all supposition misapplied,
Unhonest, false, and villainous.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Dear cousin, as you are a gentleman,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I will bless that hand,
Whose honourable pity seals the passport
For my incessant turmoils, to their rest.
If I prevail, (which heaven forbid) these ages
Which shall inherit ours, may tell posterity
Spinella had Malfato for a kinsman,
By noble love made jealous of her fame.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: No more, I dare not hear it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: All is said:
Henceforth shall never syllable proceed,
From my unpleasant voice, of amorous folly --

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Your summons warned me hither, I am come
Sister, my sister it was an unkind part,
Not to take me along with ye.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Chide her for it,
Castanna, this house is as freely yours,
As ever was your fathers.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: we conceive so,
Though your late strangeness hath bred marvel in us,
But wherefore, sister, keeps your silence distance?
Am I not welcome to ye?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Lives Auria safe?
O prithee do not hear me call him husband,
before thou canst resolve what kind of wife
His fury terms the run away, speak quickly,
Yet do not stay Castanna, I am lost,
His friend hath set before him a bad woman,
And he, good man, believes it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Now in truth --

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Hold, my heart trembles, I perceive thy tongue
Is great with ills and hastes to be delivered,
I should not use Castanna so, first tell me,
Shortly and truly tell me how he does.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: In perfect health.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: For that my thanks to heaven.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The world hath not another wife like this,
Cousin you will not hear your sister speak,
So much your passion rules.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Even what she pleases: go on Castanna.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Your most noble husband
Is deaf to all reports, and only grieves
At his souls love, Spinellas causeless absence.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why look ye cousin now?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Will value no counsel, takes no pleasure in his greatness,
Neither admits of likelihood at all,
That you are living: if you were he is certain
It were impossible you could conceal
Your welcomes to him, being all one with him,
But as for jealousy of your dishonour,
He both laughs at and scorns it.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Does he

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Therein he shows himself desertful of his happiness,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Methinks the news should cause some motion sister.
You are not well.

sp.speaker: Mal,
sp.l: Not well.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: I am unworthy.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Of whom? what? why?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Go cousin, come Castanna.

div.stage: Exeunt. Enter Trelcatio, Piero, and Futilli.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: The state in counsel is already set,
My coming will be late; now therefore gentlemen,
This house is free as your intents are sober,
Your pains shall be accepted.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Mirth sometimes falls into earnest seignior.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: We for our parts aim at the best.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: You wrong yourselves and me else, good success to ye.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Futilli it is our wisest course to follow
Our pastime with discretion, by which means
We may ingratiate as our business hits,
Our undertakings to great Aurias favour.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: I grow quite weary of this lazy custom
Attending on the fruitless hopes of service,
For meat and rags, a wit, a shrewd preferment
Study some scurril jests, grow old and beg
No let them be admired that love foul linen.
I will run a new course.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Get the coin we spend,
And knock them over the pate who jeers our earnings --

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Hushed man, one suitor comes.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: The tother follows.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Be not so loud -- here comes Madonna sweet lips.
Mistress, intruth for sooth, will lisp it to us.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
Gentlemen then ye is this music yours, or can ye
tell what great man's fiddleth, made it this very pretty noise but
who should send it.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: does not yourself know Lady.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
I do not use
To spend lip labour upon questions,
That I myself can answer.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: No sweet madam,
Your lips are destined to a better use,
Or else the proverb fails of lisping maids.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
Kithing you mean pey come behind with your mocks then,
My lips will serve the one to kith the other --
How now what next?

sp.speaker: SONG.
sp.l: What ho we come to be merry,
Open the doors a Jovial crew,
Lusty boys and free, and very,
Very, very lusty boys are we
We can drink till all look blue,
Dance sing and roar,
Never give over.
As long as we have never an eye to see
Pithee, pithee, let us come in,
We shall all your favours win,
gently, gently, we shall pass,
None kisseth like the lisping lass.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: What call ye this a song?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Yes a delicious thing, and wondereth pretty,

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: A very country catch -- doubtless some prince
Belike hath sent it to congratulate
Your nights repose.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
Think ye so seignor,
It must be then some unknown obscure prince
That shuns the light.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Perhaps the prince of darkness.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Of darkeneth what is he?

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: A courtier matchless
He woes, and wins, more beauties to his love
Than all the kings on earth.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Where stands his court pey --

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: This gentleman approaching I presume,
Has more relation to his court than I,
And comes in time to inform ye.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Think ye so? I am sure you know him,

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Lady you will perceive it.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: She seems in my first entrance to admire me,
Protest she eyes me round; Fulg. she is is thine own.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Noble Fulgoso.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Did you hear the music?
It was I that brought it, was it not tickling? ah ha

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Pay what prince sent it.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Prince, no Prince but we,
We set the ditty and composed the song,
There is not a note or foot in it, but our own,
And the pure trodden mortar of this brain,
We can do things and things.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Good sing it yourself then.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I could never sing
More than a gib cat, or a very owlet,
But you shall hear me whistle it.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
This sings some jester,
Sure he belongeth unto the prince of darkneth.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p:
Yes, and I will tell you what his office is,
His Prince delights himself exceedingly
In birds of divers kinds, this gentleman
Is keeper and instructor of his black-birds, he took his skill first
from his fathers carter.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
It is wonderful to see by what strange means
Some men are raised to places.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I do hear you,
