And thank ye heartily for your good wills,
In setting forth my parts, but what I live on,
Is simple trade of money from my lands.
Hang sharks, I am no shifter.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Is it possible --

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: O it is the man of might.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: May my address to beauty lay no scandal
Upon my martial honour, since even Mars
Whom as in war, in love I imitate,
Could not resist the shafts of Cupid, therefore
As with the god of War, I deign to stoop.
Lady vouchsafe loves goddess like to yield
Your fairer hand unto these lips, the portals
Of valiant breath, that hath overturned an army.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Fair weather, keep me, what a storm is this?

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: O Don keep off at further distance yet
A little farther, do you not observe
How your strong breath hath terrified the Lady?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: I will stop the breath of war and breath as gently
As a perfumed pair of sucking bellows
In some sweet Ladies chamber, for I can
Speak Lion-like, or sheep like, when I please.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Stand by then, without noise a while brave Don
And let her only view your parts, they will take her.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: I will publish them in silence.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Stand you there
Fulgoso the magnificent.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Just there,
Let her survey you both; you will be her choice
Never doubt it, man.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: I cannot doubt it, man.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: But speak not till I bid you.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I may whistle.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: A little to yourself, to spend the time.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Both fools you say.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: But hear them for your sport.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Don shall begin, -- begin Don, she has surveyed
Your outwards and your inwards through the rents,
And wounds of your apparel.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: She is politic,
My out-side Lady shrouds a prince obscured;

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: I thank ye for your music prince.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: My words
Are music to her.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
The music and the song
You sent me by this whistling thing, your man?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: She took him for my man, love thou wert just.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I would not hold, his man it is time to speak
Before my time, O scurvy, I his man?
That has no means for meat or rags, and seam-rents.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Have I with this one rapier.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: He has no other.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Past through a field of pikes, whose heads I lopped
As easily as the bloody minded youth
Lopped off the poppy heads.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: The puppet heads.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Have I -- have I -- have I?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Thou liest thou hast not,

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Have I -- but let that pass,
For though my famous acts were damned to silence,
Yet my descent shall crown me thy superior.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: That I would listen to.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: List and wonder,
My great, great Grandsire was an ancient Duke,

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: That is in Spanish
An incorrigible rogue, without a fellow,
An unmatched rogue, he thinks we understand not.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: So was my grandfather height Argozile.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: An arrant, arrant thief leader, pray mock it.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: My grandsire by the mothers side a Condee,
Condee Scrivano.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: A crop-eared Scrivener.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Whose son, my mothers father was a Marquis,

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: That is the son of a whore.
And my renowned sire Don Piccaco.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: In proper sense a rascal -- O brave Don.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Huio di una pravado --

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: He goes on,
Son of a branded bitch -- high spirited Don,

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Had honours both by sea and land, to wit.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: The Gallies and Bride-well.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I will not endure it,
To hear a canting mongrel -- Hear me lady,

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: It is no fair play.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I care not fair or foul,
I from a King derive my pedigree,
King Oberon by name, from whom my father
The mighty and courageous Mounti-banco,
Was lineally Descended, and my mother
(In right of whose blood I must ever honour
The lower Germany) was a Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: He blow up
The Spaniard presently by his mother side.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Her father was Grave Hansvan Herne, the son
Of Hogen Mogen, that de droates did sneighen
Of thirteen hundred Spaniards in one night.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: ODiabolo.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Ten thousand Devils, nor Diabolos
Shall fright me from my pedigree, my uncle
Yacob van Flagon drought, with Abraham Snorten fert
And youngster Brogen foh with fourscore hargubush,
Managed by well-lined Butter-boxes, took
A thousand Spanish Iobber-nowles by surprise,
And beat a sconce about their ears.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: My fury
Is now but justice on thy forfeit life.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: Lath they shall not fight.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Fear not, sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Be advised great spirits.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: My fortunes bid me to be wise in duels,
Else hanged, who cares?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Mine honour is my tutor,
Already tried and known.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Why there is the point,
Mine honour is my tutor too, Noble men
Fight in their persons, scorn it, it is out of fashion,
There is none but hare-brained youths of metal use it.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Yet put not up your swords, it is the pleasure
Of the fair Lady, that you quit the field,
With brandished blades in hand.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: And more to show
your suffering valour, as her equal favours,
you both should take a competence of kicks.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fut., Pie.
sp.l: Thus and thus, away you brace of stinkards,

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Pheugh, is it were.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Why since it is her pleasure, I dare and will endure it.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Pheugh.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Away, but stay below.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: Budge not, I charge ye,
Till you have further leave.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: Mine honour claims
The last foot in the field.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I will lead the van then.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: yet more, be gone, are not these precious suitors --

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: What tumults fright the house?

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: A brace of Coistrels,
That flattered sir, about this lovely game
your daughter, but they durst not give the souse
And so took hedge.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Me Haggards, Buzzards, Kites.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
I scorn, such trump and will shape my luff,
Henceforth shall my father best direct me.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: Why now thou singest in tune, my Amoretta,
And my good friends, you have likewise Physicians,
Prescribed a healthful diet, I shall thinkon
A bounty for your pains, and will present ye
To noble Auria: such as your Descents
Commend, but for the present we must quit
This room to privacy: they come --

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p:
Nay prithee,
Leave me not Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: We are your servants.

div.stage: exeunt. Enter Auria, Adurni, and Aurelio,

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: You are welcome, be assured you are, for proof,
Retrieve the boldness (as you please to term it)
Of visit to commands, if this man's presence
Be not of use, dismiss him.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: It is (with favour)
Of consequence my Lord, your friend may witness
How far my reputation stands engaged
To noble reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: I observe
No party here amongst us, who can challenge
A motion of such honour.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: Could your looks
Borrow more clear severity and calmness,
Than can the peace of a composed soul;
Yet I presume, report of my attempt
(Trained by a curiosity in youth)
For scattering clouds before them, hath raised tempests
Which will at last break out.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Hid now (most likely)
in the darkness of your speech.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: you may be plainer.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: I shall my Lord, that I intended wrong,

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Ha? wrong? to whom?

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: To Auria, and as far
As language could prevail, did --

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Take advice,
(Young Lord) before thy tongue betray a secret
Concealed yet from the world; hear and consider
In all my flight of vanity and giddiness,
When scarce the wings of my excess were fledged,
When a distemperature of youthful heat,
Might have excused disorder and ambition,
Even then, and so from thence till now the down
Of softness is exchanged for plumes of age,
Confirmed and hardened, never durst I pitch
On any howsoever likely rest,
Where the presumption might be construed wrong,
The word is hateful, and the sense wants pardon:
For as I durst not wrong the meanest, so
He who but only aimed by any boldness,
A wrong to me, should find I must not bear it,
The one is as unmanly as the other.
Now without interruption.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: Stand Aurelio,
And justify thine accusation boldly,
Spare me the needless use of my confession,
And having told no more, than what thy jealousy
Possessed thee with again before my face,
Urge to thy friend the breach of hospitality
Adurni trespassed in, and thou conceivest
Against Spinella; why proofs grow faint,
If barely not supposed, I will answer guilty.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: You come not here to brave us.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: No Aurelio.
But to reply upon that brittle evidence,
To which thy cunning never shall rejoin.
I make my Judge my Jury, be accountant
Whither withal the eagerness of spleen
Of a suspicious rage can plead, thou hast
Enforced the likelihood of scandal.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Doubt not
But that I have delivered honest truth,
As much as I believe, and justly witness.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: Loose grounds to raise a bulwark of reproach on,
And thus for that; my errand hither is not
In whining truant-like submission,
To cry I have offended, pray forgive me,
I will do so no more: but to proclaim
The power of virtue, whose commanding sovereignty,
Sets bounds to rebel-bloods, and check restrains,
Custom of folly by example teaches
A rule to reformation; by rewards,
Crowns worthy actions, and invites to honour.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Honour and worthy actions, best beseem
Their lips who practice both, and not discourse them.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Peace, peace, man, I am silent.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: Some there are,
And they not few in number, who resolve
No beauty can be chaste, less unattempted;
And for because the liberty of courtship
Flies from the wanton, on the her comes next,
Meeting oft times, too many soon seduced,
Conclude, all may be won by gifts, by service,
Or complements of vows; and with this file
I stood in rank, conquest secured my confidence,
Spinella (storm not Auria) was an object
Of study for fruition; here I angled
Not doubting the deceit could find resistance.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: After confession follows --

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Noise observe him.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: O strange: by all the comforts of my hopes
I found a woman good; a woman good,
Yet as I wish belief, or do desire
A memorable mention, so much majesty
Of humbleness, and scorn, appeared at once
In fair, in chaste, in wise Spinellas eyes,
That I grew dull in utterance, and one frown
From her, could every flame of sensual appetite.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: On sir and do not stop.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: Without protests,
I pleaded merely love, used not a syllable,
But what a virgin might without a blush,
Have listened to, and not well armed have pitied,
But she neglecting, cried come Auria, come
Fight for thy wife at home, then in rushed you sir
Talked in much fury, parted, when as soon
The Lady vanished, after her the rest.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: What followed?

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: My commission on mine error,
In execution whereof I have proved
So punctually severe, that I renounce
All memory, not to this one fault alone
But to my other greater, and more irksome,
Now he who ever owns a name, that construes
This repetition, the report of fear.
Of falsehood, or imposture, let him tell me
I give myself the lie, and I will clear
The injury, and man to man, or if
Such justice may prove doubtful, two to two,
Or three to three, or any way reprieve
The opinion of my forfeit, without blemish.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Who can you think I am? did you expect
So great a tameness as you find, Adurni,
That you cast loud defiance? Say --

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: I have robbed you
Of rigour (Auria) by my strict self-penance,
For the presumption.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Sure Italians hardly
Admit dispute in questions of this nature,
The trick is new.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: I find my absolution,
By vows of change from all ignoble practice.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Why look ye friend, I told you this before
You would not be persuaded, -- let me think.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: You do not yet deny that you solicited
The Lady to ill purpose.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: I have answered,
But it returned much quiet to my mind,
Perplexed with rare commotions.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: That is the way
It smooths all rubs.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Foh I am thinking
You may talk forward, if it take it is clear
And then and then, and so and so.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: You labour with curious engines sure,

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Fine ones, I take ye
To be a man of credit -- else,

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: Suspicion is needless, know me better.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Yet you must not part from me sir.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: For that your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Come fight for thy wife at home my Auria -- yes
We can fight my Spinella, when thine honour
Relies upon a Champion -- now.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: My Lord
Castanna with her sister, and Malfato
Are newly entered.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Be not loud; convey them
Into the gallery -- Aurelio, friend
Adurni Lord, we three will sit in counsel
And piece a hearty league, or scuffle shrewdly.

div.head: Actus Quintus.

sp.speaker: Martino.
sp.l: Ruffian out of my doors, thou comest to rob me,
An officer, what ho! my house is haunted
By a lewd pack of thieves, of harlots, murtherers,
Rogues, vagabonds, I foster a decoy here,
And she trolls on her ragged customer,
To cut my throat for pillage.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Good sir hear me,

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Hear or not hear, let him rave his lungs out,
Whiles this woman hath abode under this roof,
I will justify herself her bedfellow in despite
Of denial, in despite, those are my words.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Monstrous! why sirrah, do I keep a bawdy-house,
An hospital for panders? O thou monster,
Thou she-confusion! are you grown so rampant,
That from a private wanton thou proclaimest thyself
A baggage for all gamesters, Lords or Gentlemen,
Strangers, or home-spun yeomen, foot-posts, pages,
Roarers or hangmen, hey day, set up shop,
And then cry a market open, to it, and welcome.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: This is my husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Husband!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Husband natural, I have married her,
And what is your verdict on the match seignior?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Husband, and married her!

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Indeed it is truth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A proper joining, give ye joy great mistress
Your fortunes are advanced, marry are they,
What jointure is assured pray? some three thousand
A year in oaths and vermin? fair preferment.
Was ever such a tattered rag of man's flesh,
Patched up for Copesmate to my Nieces daughter.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Sir, for my mothers name forbear this anger,
If I have yoked myself beneath your wishes,
Yet is my choice a lawful one, and I
Will live as truly chaste unto his bosom,
As ere my faith hath bound me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A sweet couple.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: We are so, for mine own part, however my out-side
Appear ungay, I have wrestled with death,
Seignior Martino, to preserve your sleeps, and such
As you are untroubled, a soldier is in peace
A mockery, a very town bull for laughter, unthrifts,
And landed babies, are prey-curmudgeons,
Lay their baits for, let the wars rattle about
Your ears once, and the security of a soldier is
Right honourable amongst ye then, that day
May shine again: so to my business.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A soldier! thou a soldier, I do believe
Thou art lousy; that is a pretty sign I grant:
A villainous poor Bandetti rather, one
Can man a quean, and cant, and pick a pocket,
Pad for a cloak, or hat, and in the dark
Pistol a straggler for a quarter Ducat.
A soldier! yes, he looks as if he had not
The spirit of a herring, or a tumbler.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Let age and dotage rage together, Levidolche thou art
mine, on what conditions the world shall soon witness: yet since
our hands joined, I have not interested my possession of thy bed,
nor till I have accounted to thy injunction, do I mean: kiss me
quick and resolute. So adieu Seignior.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Dear, for loves sake, stay.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Forbear entreaties.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ah thou: but what? I know not how to call thee,
Fain would I smother grief, and out it must,
My heart is broke, thou hast for many a day
Been at a loss, and now art lost for ever:
Lost, lost, without recovery.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: With pardon,
Let me retain your sorrows.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is impossible,
Despair of rising up to honest fame,
Turns all the courses wild, and this last action
Will roar thy infamy, then you are certainly
Married forsooth, unto this new-come.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Yes, and herein every hope is brought to life,
Which long hath lain in deadness, I have once more
Wedded Benatzi my divorced husband,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Benatzi, this the man?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: No odd disguise
Could guard him from discovery; it is he,
The choice of my ambition, heaven preserve me
Thankful for such a bounty; yet he dreams not
Of this deceit, but let me die in speaking,
If I repute not my success more happy
Than any earthly blessing; O sweet uncle,
Rejoice with me, I am a faithful convert,
And will redeem the stains of a foul name,
By love and true obedience.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Force of passion
Shows me a child again, do Levidolche,
Perform thy resolutions, those performed,
I have been only steward for your welfare,
You shall have all between ye.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Join with me sir,
Our plot requires much speed: we must be earnest,
I will tell ye what conditions threaten danger,
Unless you intermediate; let us hasten,
For fear we come too late.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As thou intendest
A virtuous honesty, I am thy second
To any office, Levidolche witty,
My Niece, my witty Niece.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Let us slack no time sir.

div.stage: Exeunt. Enter Trelcatio, Malfato, Spinella and Castanna.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: Kinsman and Ladies, have a little patience,
All will be as you wish, I will be your warrant,
Fear nothing, Augia is a noble fellow,
I leave ye; but be sure I am in hearing:
Take courage.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Courage, they who have no hearts,
Find none to lose; ours is as great as his,
Who defy danger most, sure state and ceremony
In habit here like strangers we shall wait
Formality of entertainment, Cousin,
Let us return, it is paltry.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Gentle sir,
Confine your passion, my attendance only
Commends a duty.
Now for heavens sake sister --
He comes, your husband comes, take comfort sister

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Malfato.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Auria.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Cousin, would mine arms
In their embraces might at once deliver
Affectionately what interest your merit
Holds in my estimation, I may chide
The coyness of this intercourse betwixt us,
Which a retired privacy on your part
Hath pleased to show; if ought of my endeavours
Can purchase kind opinion, I shall honour
The means and practice.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: It is your charity.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Worthy Malfato.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Provident Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Castanna, virtuous maid,

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Your servant, brother.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: But who is that other, such a face mine eyes
Have been acquainted with, the sight resembles
Something which is not quite lost to remembrance;
Why does the Lady kneel? to whom? pray rise;
I shall forget civility of manners,
Imagining you tender, a false tribute,
Or him to whom you tender it, a counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: My Lord, you use a borrowed bravery,
Not suiting fair constructions, may your fortunes
Mount higher than can apprehension reach them,
Yet this waste kind of antique soveraigned
Unto a wife who equals every best
Of your deserts, achievements, or posterity,
Bewrays a barrenness of noble nature,
Let upstarts exercise uncomely roughness,
Clear spirits to the humble will be humble:
You know your wife no doubt.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Cry ye mercy Gentleman,
Belike you come to tutor a good carriage,
Are expert in the nick on it we shall study
Instructions quaintly, wife you said, agreed.
Keep fair, and stand the trial.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Those words raise
A lively soul in her, who almost yielded
To faintness and stupidity, I thank ye,
Though prove what judge you will, till I can purge
Objections which require belief and conscience,
I have no kindred sister, husband, friend,
Or pity for my plea.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Call ye this welcome? we are mistook Castanna.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O my Lord, other respects were promised.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Said ye Lady,
No kindred, sister, husband, friend.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Nor name,
With this addition, I disclaim all benefit
Of mercy from a charitable thought,
If one or all the subtleties of malice,
If any engineer of faithless discord,
If supposition for pretence in folly,
Can point out, without injury to goodness,
A likelihood of guilt in my behaviour,
Which may Declare neglect in every duty,
Required fit, or exacted.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: High and peremptory,
The confidence is masculine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why not, an honourable cause gives life to truth,
Without control.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: I can proceed, that tongue,
Whose venom by traducing spotless honour,
Hath spread, the infection is not more mine enemy,
Than theirs, or his weak and besotted brains are,
On whom the poison of its cankered falsehood
Hath wrought for credit to so foul a mischief.
Speak sir, the churlish voice of this combustion,
Aurelio speak, nor (gentle sir) forbear
Ought what you know, but roundly use your eloquence
Against a mean defendant.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: He is put to it,
It seems the challenge gravels him.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: My intelligence,
Was issue of my doubts, not of my knowledge.
A self confession may crave assistance,
Let the Ladies justice impose the penance.
So in the rules of friendship, as of love,
Suspicion is not seldom an improper
Advantage for the knitting faster joints
Of faithfullest affection by the fevers
Of casualty unloosed, where lastly error
Hath run into the toil.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Woeful satisfaction for a divorce of hearts.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: So resolute,
I shall touch nearer home, behold these hairs,
(Great Masters of a spirit) yet they are not
By winter of old age quite hid in snow,
Some messengers of time I must acknowledge
Amongst them took up lodging, when we first
Exchanged our faiths in wedlock, I was proud,
I did prevail with one whose youth and beauty
Deserved a choice more suitable in both.
Advancement to a fortune could not court,
Ambition either on my side, or hers:
Love drove the bargain, and the truth of love
Confirmed it, I conceived, but disproportion
In years, amongst the married, is a reason
For change of pleasures, whereto I reply
Our union was not forced, it was by consent;
So then the breach in such a case appears
Unpardonable; say your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: My thoughts in that respect are as resolute as yours,
The same, yet herein evidence of frailty
Deserved not more a separation,
Than doth charge of disloyalty objected
Without or ground or witness, woman's faults
Subject to punishments, and men's applauded,
Prescribe no laws in force.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Are ye so nimble.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: A soul sublimed from dross by competition,
Such as is mighty Aurias famed; Descends
From its own Sphere, when injuries profound ones
Yield to the combat of a scolding mastery.
Skirmish of words hath with your wife lewdly ranged
Adulterating the honour of your bed.
Hold dispute, but execute your vengeance,
With unresisted rage we shall look, on,
Allow the fact, and spurn her from our bloods,
Else not detected, you have wronged her innocence
Unworthily, and childishly, for which
I challenge satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: It is a tyranny
Over an humble and obedient sweetness,
Ungently to insult --

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: That I make good,
And must without exception find admittance
Fitting the party who hath her in interest,
Put case I was in fault, that fault stretched merely
To a misguided thought, and who in presence
Except the pair of fisters fair and matchless,
Can quit an imputation of like folly?
Here I ask pardon (excellent Spinella
Of only you) that granted he amongst you,
Who calls an even reckoning, shall meet
An even accountant.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Baited by confederacy,
I must have right.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: And I, my Lord, my Lord,
What stir and coil is here? you can suspect,
So reconciliation then is needless,
Conclude the difference by revenge, or part,
And never more see one another: sister,
Lend me thine arm, I have assumed a courage
Above my force, and can hold out no longer,
Auria unkind, unkind.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: She faints.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Spinella, regent of my affections, thou hast conquered,
I find thy vertues as I left them, perfect,
Pure, and unflawed, for instance let me claim
Castannas promise.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Mine?

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Yours, to whose faith
I am a guardian, not by imposition,
But by you chosen, look ye, I have fitted
A husband for you, noble and deserving,
No shrinking back, Adurni I present her
A wife of worth.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How is that?

sp.speaker: Advr.
sp.l: So great a blessing
Crowns all desires of life, the motion, Lady,
To me, I can assure you, is not sudden,
But welcomed and forethought, would you could please
To say the like.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Castanna do -- Speak dearest,
It rectifies all crooks, vain surmises,
I prithee speak.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: The courtship is somewhat quick,
The match it seems agreed on, do not sifter
Reject the use of fate.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I dare not question
The will of heaven.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Unthought of and unlooked for.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: My ever honoured Lord.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: This marriage frees
Each circumstance of jealousy.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Make no scruple
(Castanna) of the choice, it is firm and real,
Why else have I so long with tameness nourished
Report of wrongs, but that I fixed on issue
Of my desires, Italians use not dalliance
But execution; herein I degenerated
From custom of our nation: for the vertues
Of my Spinella rooted in my soul,
Yet common form of matrimonial complements,
Short lived, as are their pleasures, yet in sooth,
My dearest, I might blame your causeless absence,
To whom my love and nature were no strangers,
But being in your kinsman's house, I honour
His hospitable friendship, and must thank it.
Now lasting truce on all hands.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: You will pardon
A rash and over-busy curiosity.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: It was too blame, but the success remits it.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Sir, what presumptions formerly have grounded
Opinion of unfitting carriage to you,
On my part I shall faithfully acquit
At easy summons.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You prevent the nicety,
Use your own pleasure --

div.stage: Enter Benatzi, his sword drawn, Levidolche and Martino following.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Matter?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Adurni and Malfato found together!
Now for a glorious vengeance.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Hold, O hold him.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: This is no place for murder, yield thy sword.
Yield it, or force it; set you up your shambles
Of slaughter in my presence.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: Let him come.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What can the Ruffian mean?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I am prevented.
The temple or the chamber of the Duke,
Had else not proved a sanctuary Lord,
Thou hast dishonourably wronged my wife.

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: Thy wife! I know not her, nor thee.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Yes, me you know, heaven has a gentle mercy
For penitent offenders: blessed Ladies,
Repute me not a cast-away, though once
I fell into some lapses, which our sex
Are oft entangled by; yet what I have been,
Concerns me now no more, who am resolved
On a new life. This Gentleman Benatzi,
Disguised as you see, I have re-married,
I knew you at first sight, and tender constantly
Submission for all errors.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, it is true sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I joy in the discovery, am thankful
Unto the change.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Let wonder henceforth cease,
For I am partner with Benatzis counsels;
And in them was director, I have seen
The man do service in the wars late past,
Worthy an ample mention; but of that
At large hereafter, repetitions now
Of good or bad, would straighten time presented
For other use.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Welcome, and welcome ever.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Mine eyes sir, never shall without a blush
Receive a look from yours; please to forget
All passages of rashness, such attempt
Was mine, and only mine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You have found a way
To happiness, I honour the conversion,

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: Then I am freed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: may style your friend your servant,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now all that is mine, is theirs,

sp.speaker: Adur.
sp.l: But let me add
An offering to the altar of this peace.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: How likes Spinella this? our holy day
Deserves the Calendar.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: This Gentlewoman
Reformed must in my thoughts live fair and worthy,
Indeed you shall.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: And mine, the novelty
Requires a friendly love.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: You are kind and bountiful.

div.stage: Enter Trelcatio, Futelli, Amoretta, Piero, driving in Fulgosa, and Guzman.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: By your leaves Lords and Ladies, to your jollities,
I bring increase with mine too, here is a youngster
Whom I call son-in-law, for so my daughter
Will have it.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.l: Yes in sooth she will.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: Futelli hath weaned her from this pain.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Stand forth stout lovers.

sp.speaker: Trel.
sp.l: Top and Top-gallant pair, and for his pains,
She will have him, or none, he is not the richest
In the parish; but a wit, I say Amen,
Because I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.l: It is no matter.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: We will remedy the penury of Fortune,
They shall with us to Corsica, our cousin
Must not despair of means, since it is believed
Futelli can deserve a place of trust.

sp.speaker: Fut.
sp.l: You are in all unfellowed,

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Think on Piero sir.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Piero, yes,
But what of these two pretty ones?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I will follow.
The Ladies, play at cards, make sport and whistle,
My purse shall bear me out, a lazy life,
Is scurvy, and debauched; fight you abroad,
And we will be game whiles you fight at home,
Run high, run low, here is a brain can do it,
But for my martial brother Don, prithee make him
A what do ye call it, a setting dog, a sentinel
I will mend his weekly pay.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.l: He shall deserve it.
Vouchsafe employment honourable

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Marry.
The Don is a generous Don.

sp.speaker: Auri.
sp.l: Unfit to lose him,
Command doth limit us short time for revels,
We must be thrifty in them, none I trust,
Repines at these delights, they are free and harmless,
After distress at sea, the dangers over,
Safety and welcomes better taste a shore.

sp.speaker: EPILOGVE.
sp.l: The Court is on rising; it is too late
To wish the Lady in her fate
Of trial now more fortunate.
A verdict in the Juries breast,
Will be given up anon at least,
Till then it is fit we hope the best.
Else if there can be any stay,
Next sitting without more delay,
We will expect a gentle day.
